awd_titl_txt: EAGER: An ultradian cycle that mediates metabolic homeostasis under extreme conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
Oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) provides the majority of free energy for most eukaryotic cells. Remarkably, inhibition of OXPHOS for extended periods of time is well tolerated by cells, through compensation by glycolysis. The systems-level properties that enable such metabolic adaptation are yet to be understood. The PI previously observed a cycling of metabolism on inhibition of OXPHOS. This project investigates how cells manage their energy budget dynamically to withstand OXPHOS inhibition. By identifying these mechanisms, the project enables a range of future investigations that will establish the function and significance of metabolic cycling within physiological circumstances. This project is developing an extracurricular program for undergraduates and high school students that introduces them to current research concepts in metabolic biochemistry, cell fate regulation, and dynamical systems modeling. Activities include reading and presentation of primary literature, construction of pathway maps using CellDesigner software, and contribution to the writing of reviews that will be submitted for publication or posted to public websites. Students learn about the process of conducting research, and the applications of research findings to human or veterinary medicine and metabolic engineering.

Oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) provides the majority of free energy for most eukaryotic cells. Remarkably, inhibition of OXPHOS for extended periods of time is well tolerated by cells when sufficient glucose and other nutrients are available. Mammalian cells can survive full OXPHOS inhibition and continue to proliferate, even though ATP generation per glucose molecule is reduced from approximately 36 to only 2. Their survival is enabled by a seemingly seamless switch to glycolysis, which has largely been assumed to occur uniformly in time within all cells of a population. However, recent work from the PI’s lab has revealed, using live-cell biosensors, that OXPHOS inhibition induces large oscillations in the activity of AMPK, a key regulator of metabolic status. Similar oscillations in AMPK activity occur in multiple cell types and have a characteristic period of about 3 hours, regardless of which mitochondrial complex is inhibited. This stereotypical pattern suggests the existence of a common temporal program, which has been termed the OXPHOS Inhibition-induced Cycle (OPIC). Furthermore, additional data show that the activity of AMPK, which stimulates catabolism, alternates with the activity of ERK and mTORC1, which are key pro-anabolic signaling pathways. These data imply that metabolic homeostasis is temporally organized into phases dedicated to distinct metabolic processes. This project is undertaken to identify the network underlying cell cycle-independent, hours-scale periodicity in mammalian cellular metabolism. The mechanisms driving OPIC are examined by (1) disabling the cycle to determine its importance, (2) determining the functional role of the cycle in metabolism and (3) to identify the regulators and readouts of the cycle.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand why human cells undergo regular oscillations in energetic activity when they are prevented from using mitochondria to oxidize their fuel sources. Oxidative phosphorylation, or OxPhos, is a central part of metabolism, and it can be inhibited by drugs, environmental toxins, or pathogens. Defining the mechanisms of the oscillations that occur when OxPhos is inhibited is an important step toward a complete model for how cells use feedback loops to maintain their metabolic homeostasis. A major question that we addressed in this project was whether the rate of glycolysis fluctuates as part of these periodic changes. We approached this question by analyzing a fluorescent biosensor for a key intermediate sugar in the glycolytic pathway. We also developed a new red fluorescent biosensor for AMPK, a cellular protein that serves as a central energetic sensor for the cell. These sensors indicated that the rate of glycolysis does in fact oscillate under OxPhos inhibition and that it is very closely tied to the activity of AMPK. These observations supported one of our main hypotheses, which is that cycling is driven in part by periodic exhaustion of NAD+, a key co-factor that is required for glycolysis. We also examined the effects of various inhibitors on the rates of glycolysis, which provided further evidence that a buildup of citrate, which is produced by the Krebs cycle, may also create sudden drops in glycolysis rates, strengthening the oscillations.  Another major question we addressed was whether changes in the structure of the mitochondria, or changes in the cell’s ability to recycle its components, known as autophagy, are involved in the bioenergetic cycling. Analysis of gene expression changes during OxPhos inhibition revealed little evidence for the involvement of either mitochondria or autophagy, but instead showed an unexpectedly strong signature for endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. As the main site for protein and lipid synthesis, the ER can play a major role in cellular bioenergetics. Our data suggest that tuning of this biosynthesis rate of the ER may contribute to the oscillations induced by OxPhos inhibition. In summary, our results identify the main molecular routes and feedback loops that cause oscillations in cellular bioenergetics under stressful conditions. These findings will be the basis for more precise mathematical models that capture the relevant feedback effects and provide accurate predictions of cellular metabolic behavior under a wide range of conditions. This project also enabled the training of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in modern molecular metabolism, including in basic concepts and key literature studies, experimental techniques such as fluorescence microscopy and biosensor engineering, and computational bioinformatics analysis.
